text: The Lord spoke his word to Jonah, son of Amittai. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Leave at once for the important city, Nineveh. Announce to the people that I can no longer overlook the wicked things they have done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonah immediately tried to run away from the Lord by going to Tarshish. He went to Joppa and found a ship going to Tarshish. He paid for the trip and went on board. He wanted to go to Tarshish to get away from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord sent a violent wind over the sea. The storm was so powerful that the ship was in danger of breaking up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sailors were afraid, and they cried to their gods for help. They began to throw the cargo overboard to lighten the ship’s load.
Now, Jonah had gone below deck and was lying there sound asleep.
speaker: Narrator

text: The captain of the ship went to him and asked, “How can you sleep? Get up, and pray to your God. Maybe he will notice us, and we won’t die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the sailors said to each other, “Let’s throw dice to find out who is responsible for bringing this disaster on us.” So they threw dice, and the dice indicated that Jonah was responsible.
speaker: Narrator

text: They asked him, “Tell us, why has this disaster happened to us? What do you do for a living? Where do you come from? What country are you from? What nationality are you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonah answered them, “I’m a Hebrew. I worship the Lord, the God of heaven. He is the God who made the sea and the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men were terrified. They knew that he was running away from the Lord, because he had told them. They asked Jonah, “Why have you done this?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The storm was getting worse. So they asked Jonah, “What should we do with you to calm the sea?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, “Throw me overboard. Then the sea will become calm. I know that I’m responsible for this violent storm.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Instead, the men tried to row harder to get the ship back to shore, but they couldn’t do it. The storm was getting worse.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they cried to the Lord for help: “Please, Lord, don’t let us die for taking this man’s life. Don’t hold us responsible for the death of an innocent man, because you, Lord, do whatever you want.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they took Jonah and threw him overboard, and the sea became calm.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men were terrified of the Lord. They offered sacrifices and made vows to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord sent a big fish to swallow Jonah. Jonah was inside the fish for three days and three nights.
speaker: Narrator

text: From inside the fish Jonah prayed to the Lord his God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jonah prayed:
“I called to the Lord in my distress,
and he answered me.
From the depths of my watery grave I cried for help,
and you heard my cry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You threw me into the deep, into the depths of the sea,
and water surrounded me.
All the whitecaps on your waves have swept over me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then I thought,
‘I have been banished from your sight.
Will I ever see your holy temple again?’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Water surrounded me, threatening my life.
The deep sea covered me completely.
Seaweed was wrapped around my head.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I sank to the foot of the mountains.
I sank to the bottom,
where bars held me forever.
But you brought me back from the pit, O Lord, my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“As my life was slipping away, I remembered the Lord.
My prayer came to you in your holy temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who hold on to worthless idols abandon their loyalty to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I will sacrifice to you with songs of thanksgiving.
I will keep my vow.
Victory belongs to the Lord!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to the fish, and it spit Jonah out onto the shore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke his word to Jonah a second time. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Leave at once for the important city, Nineveh. Announce to the people the message I have given you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonah immediately went to Nineveh as the Lord told him. Nineveh was a very large city. It took three days to walk through  it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonah entered the city and walked for about a day. Then he said, “In forty days Nineveh will be destroyed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Nineveh believed God. They decided to fast, and everyone, from the most important to the least important, dressed in sackcloth.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the news reached the king of Nineveh, he got up from his throne, took off his robe, put on sackcloth, and sat in ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he made this announcement and sent it throughout the city:
“This is an order from the king and his nobles: No one is to eat or drink anything. This includes all people, animals, cattle, and sheep.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every person and animal must put on sackcloth. Cry loudly to God for help. Turn from your wicked ways and your acts of violence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who knows? God may reconsider his plans and turn from his burning anger so that we won’t die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God saw what they did. He saw that they turned from their wicked ways. So God reconsidered his threat to destroy them, and he didn’t do it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonah was very upset about this, and he became angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he prayed to the Lord, “Lord, isn’t this what I said would happen when I was still in my own country? That’s why I tried to run to Tarshish in the first place. I knew that you are a merciful and compassionate God, patient, and always ready to forgive and to reconsider your threats of destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, Lord, take my life. I’d rather be dead than alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord asked, “What right do you have to be angry?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonah left the city and sat down east of it. He made himself a shelter there. He sat in its shade and waited to see what would happen to the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God made a plant grow up beside Jonah to give him shade and make him more comfortable. Jonah was very happy with the plant.
speaker: Narrator

text: At dawn the next day, God sent a worm to attack the plant so that it withered.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sun rose, God made a hot east wind blow. The sun beat down on Jonah’s head so that he was about to faint. He wanted to die. So he said, “I’d rather be dead than alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then God asked Jonah, “What right do you have to be angry over this plant?”
Jonah answered, “I have every right to be angry—so angry that I want to die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord replied, “This plant grew up overnight and died overnight. You didn’t plant it or make it grow. Yet, you feel sorry for this plant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shouldn’t I feel sorry for this important city, Nineveh? It has more than 120,000 people in it as well as many animals. These people couldn’t tell their right hand from their left.”
speaker: Narrator
